That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I reside in a small Michigan town that exemplifies rural America, where farmlands blend into quaint tourist destinations. We're far from urban amenities - no major shopping centers or chain restaurants. While everything requires driving to reach, our location is extraordinarily beautiful, nestled between Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix, with abundant waterfront access everywhere you turn.

Our neighborhood embodies small-town charm, with diverse housing styles spread comfortably apart. Unlike modern subdivisions, these homes have character - mostly older structures, some renovated, others maintaining their original charm, typically featuring full basements and classic aluminum siding in various colors. The properties are spacious, featuring children's play equipment, gardens, and fenced yards for pets.

The community reflects middle-class America, populated by hardworking families. There's constant activity - children playing, people exercising, and neighbors socializing. Everyone knows each other, making it easy to spot outsiders. Friendly waves and smiles are commonplace, whether someone's grilling or walking their dog. Property maintenance is consistent, with well-kept lawns, trimmed vegetation, and tidy yards. While not luxurious, it's clearly an ideal setting for raising a family - peaceful, secure, and welcoming.

The neighborhood is conveniently located near essential services: the sheriff's department, health department, and recycling center. Local attractions include baseball fields where you can hear game announcements, a small airport with its familiar sounds of aircraft, and an ice cream shop within walking distance. Downtown is accessible on foot, and children can safely bike to the nearby park. It truly represents an ideal American community, offering that coveted sense of belonging and security that people seek in a home.

I reside in what could be considered a quintessential suburban development, heavily influenced by an active homeowner's association (HOA). The neighborhood features uniform single-family residences with standardized front yards consisting of manicured lawns, decorative stones, and compact driveways. The streets are immaculately maintained with pristine concrete, and each home comes with a two-car garage. While predominantly single-story, some two-story homes dot the landscape.

Rather than individual mailboxes, we have a centralized mail station with key-accessed boxes and package lockers – another example of the HOA's preference for consistency. Our location straddles the line between rural and suburban settings at the city's periphery, providing ample space for community amenities. These include multiple gated swimming pools and extensive walking trails, making outdoor activities and exercise convenient for residents.

The demographic primarily consists of retirees, with a smaller population of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a close-knit, security-conscious community where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. Though it takes about 15 minutes to drive to major shopping areas, we have access to all essential amenities, including a modest mall and various retail options ranging from upscale organic grocery stores to budget-friendly outlets.

Overall, our neighborhood epitomizes well-maintained suburban living with excellent community facilities. While shopping isn't immediately adjacent, a short drive provides access to virtually any major retail chain or service one might need.

I discovered my current residence while listening to a true crime podcast about disappearances, which was unexpected given the area's high rental prices, typically exceeding $1,000 monthly. This story wasn't common knowledge among my social circle. Life here can be challenging - many struggle financially, but we've adapted to living frugally. You grow accustomed to thrift store scents and second-hand items, and your sensibilities change with age. Some take up smoking, while others simply adjust to their circumstances.

The neighborhood is rich with second-hand shopping opportunities - three thrift stores within walking distance, plus charity shops, a library, and specialty stores selling books and curiosities. Despite the bustling downtown area teeming with traffic and pedestrians, these thrift stores remain eerily quiet, offering peaceful refuge from the city's chaos.

This is an expanding metropolitan area, home to a major e-commerce corporation's headquarters. It reminds me of New York in how people maintain their privacy and independence. Unlike the South's characteristic friendliness and concern for others, people here respect personal boundaries and don't interfere in others' lives.

My apartment building has a vibrant atmosphere, with musicians as neighbors creating a constant backdrop of activity. We've formed a tight-knit community, sharing celebrations and sorrows, helping each other with daily tasks and forming genuine connections. Despite living in an impersonal, modern urban landscape, these neighborly relationships make it feel like home. We exchange favors, share meals, and handle each other's mail. These human connections within this vast city make me feel that my life choices weren't misguided after all.

I reside in a modest Midwestern community situated on the outskirts of a metropolitan area. My home is in the eastern section, which is considered the town's less affluent district. While property values here are modest and most residents are either renters or lower-income homeowners, the area maintains a pleasant atmosphere. The community is welcoming, with neighbors who are cordial and sociable.

Though crime rates in my area are marginally higher compared to other parts of town, they remain relatively low overall. We've experienced some serious incidents nearby over the past decade, including some gun-related violence. While we've personally only dealt with minor theft issues, our neighbors experienced tragedy when their son was killed in a shooting incident at a local establishment last year.

Like many American communities, our town struggles with the opioid crisis, particularly fentanyl-related deaths. However, we have substantial support systems in place, including rehabilitation facilities and community training for overdose prevention.

The town has numerous strengths, particularly our education system. My son's elementary school provides an inclusive, supportive environment with dedicated staff and active parent involvement. The school ensures all children are well-cared for, offering universal free meals due to the significant portion of our population living in poverty. They maintain affordable costs for all school-related expenses to ensure equal participation opportunities.

The local government has invested in community improvements, though these enhancements primarily benefit the town center and western areas where commercial activity is concentrated. This disparity in development between the east and west sides creates some tension among residents.

Despite its challenges, I'm content here. The combination of friendly people, quality schools, diverse shopping options, and our comfortable home makes it an satisfactory place to live. After more than 16 years here, we've become deeply rooted in this community and couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

I reside in a culturally rich neighborhood perched on a hill, steeped in historical significance. My seven-story apartment building faces a historic theater, and nearby there's a popular arcade bar that draws diverse crowds during summer evenings, often with queues forming on warm weekend nights in June and July. The local city park, surprisingly spacious for its urban setting, features concrete walls with broad steps. During cold winter months, it becomes a haven for the homeless community, who arrange their tents along the sidewalks and stairs. Though snow is rare, the heavy winter rains make survival challenging. The homeless prefer this central location over remote areas, as it provides warmth through community and convenient access to the region's only family center with bathing facilities.

While the neighborhood's historic architecture and ocean-facing hillside landscape are impressive, what truly captivates me is its human element. Hilltop, once infamous for gang activity on the West Coast, still echoes with stories of federal law enforcement interventions from thirty years ago. These narratives persist, passed down through generations and shared with newcomers like myself. Despite its reputation as a rough area, residents actively work to maintain their community's well-being.

There's a common warning about white people avoiding the area after dark, but I view this as an outdated perspective rooted in social prejudice. Whether it's because of my ambiguous ethnicity or because the community has accepted me, I've found a home here. The neighborhood serves as a mirror reflecting our nation's ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions, even in what's supposed to be a multicultural paradise.

Hilltop has become my true home, where I've experienced countless acts of kindness: strangers offering jackets for warmth, laundromat owners extending their hours to help, and random acts of generosity from passersby who recognize human dignity even in moments of struggle. These experiences have shown me the genuine heart of this community.

I relocated to this area when I was entering eighth grade. Though initially challenging to socialize, I eventually formed close friendships with two neighbors, who have since moved away, but their impact remains. Most original residents still live here, maintaining the typical American suburban atmosphere. The neighborhood features numerous two-story homes and regularly echoes with children's laughter during warm weather. It's generally peaceful, and neighborly interactions are respectful and helpful when needed. Package theft isn't an issue, which reflects the trustworthy nature of our community.

A nearby park holds countless memories for me, from various sports activities with neighborhood friends to recent visits with my young cousins who love the playground equipment. Despite one unfortunate incident involving a broken nose during football, the positive experiences far outweigh the negative ones. The park now evokes strong feelings of nostalgia.

Our area boasts impressive cultural diversity, evident in the variety of dining options within a mile radius - from Chinese to Italian cuisine. While food delivery apps have become increasingly popular, traditional fast food and pizza establishments remain neighborhood staples. The community is well-served by essential businesses, including pharmacies (both Walgreens and CVS), a Jewel-Osco supermarket (a Midwest favorite), multiple dry cleaners, and specialty stores like an Indian grocery shop.

Considering the neighborhood horror stories I see on social media and news, I feel fortunate to live in such a pleasant, well-rounded community that meets all my needs while maintaining a safe and friendly environment.

I live in a college-adjacent neighborhood that suits me well. The area features predominantly apartment complexes alongside several affordable dining and drinking establishments. There's a recently rebranded bar that's pricier but still offers decent service. The community is diverse, consisting mainly of college students and working-class residents, owing to the reasonable housing costs. An elementary school nearby brings many children to the area.

While I maintain distance from my neighbors, I find amusement in how management addressed their cannabis use by installing an air freshener opposite their door. The surrounding architecture is generally dated, though some units have updated interiors. New apartments have sprung up nearby, but their high rents seem unjustified given their questionable construction quality – they capitalize on their proximity to campus.

Local amenities include a budget-friendly restaurant serving simple microwaved fare and a gas station with a reportedly challenging work environment. Recent city-funded improvements have enhanced the streetscape with wider sidewalks and landscaping. My building sits among numerous trees, though some have been removed, providing more greenery than other nearby areas. The adjacent 43rd Street presents a stark contrast with deteriorating infrastructure and buildings partially concealed by trees. While crime occurs in nearby complexes, including those on 43rd Street and across from my building, I'm generally satisfied with my location. The affordable rent, convenient amenities, walkable distance to the university, and accessible public transportation make it a practical choice for my needs.

I live in a unique development consisting of duplexes arranged along a cul-de-sac. Though they're actually connected units, they're positioned to appear as separate homes, all featuring identical yellow exteriors, white porches, and green metal roofs. The community is notably close-knit, with most residents maintaining friendly relationships. We often gather spontaneously in driveways during evenings, conversing while children play nearby with various toys and activities. This lifestyle offers a welcome escape from today's technology-driven world, creating an almost nostalgic atmosphere.

Our setting is picturesque, with fields and forests surrounding us, complemented by beautiful skies. Recently, however, we faced our first serious weather challenge when tornado sirens forced us to seek shelter. I found myself huddled in my bathtub with my small dog and essential items, while my larger dog refused to leave the living room, anxiously barking at the unusual situation. The storm brought dramatic changes, including heavy hail and a sudden temperature drop from 92 to 75 degrees. Afterward, we witnessed a stunning double rainbow, which I photographed and shared with loved ones online.

Life here quickly returned to normal, with families resuming their usual outdoor activities. As a recent transplant from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I've found the Southern hospitality and accents charming. While our duplex units look identical outside, the interior layouts vary significantly. My two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment is quite spacious, though some units are surprisingly compact.

The natural surroundings are a highlight, with a large field and non-swimming pond nearby where deer roam and bullfrogs call. Located just forty minutes from Charlotte, our community offers a perfect blend of rural charm and urban accessibility. The morning rooster calls and evening donkey braying from neighboring farms add to the village-like atmosphere. I consider myself fortunate to have discovered this wonderful community.

Having spent a decade in this area, I can offer some meaningful insights about my experience. The transition from Riverdale to Stockbridge was initially challenging and emotional for me. Though I was tearful about leaving behind loved ones, my parents made this move with our best interests in mind, seeking better housing, education, and overall living conditions in a more upscale neighborhood.

As time passed, I adapted to my new environment, forming both friendships and rivalries at school. While I remained relatively distant from most neighbors, I developed close relationships with Mr. Glen's family and Dennis, who lived adjacent to us. These connections grew so strong that they became almost like family. A particularly memorable moment was attending Mr. Glen's second marriage to Ms. Veda. The celebration was delightful, and I even caught the garter belt! I especially enjoyed dancing with their daughter Marsharii, though we've lost touch since then.

The neighborhood's layout is quite complex, but GPS helps me navigate it now. I've explored parts of it with my friends Kason and Curtis, spending countless hours gaming and making the most of our youth. I find solace in visiting the local park, where I practice balance with sticks from Home Depot and sometimes bring my wooden bokken sword. The park also features basketball and tennis courts - while I haven't played either sport recently, it's comforting to know they're available. I have fond memories of playing tennis with my dad, best friend, and Mr. Graves, who pushed us hard but kept it enjoyable.

While I've accumulated many stories during my time here, these particular memories stand out the most. I remain optimistic that even better experiences await in the future!

Johnston is a modest South Carolina town that, while unremarkable at first glance, holds significance as the self-proclaimed Peach Capital of the World. The landscape is dominated by peach orchards and cattle farms, with residential properties scattered throughout. Outside the town center, homes are generously spaced, typically featuring two-story constructions with either heat-reflecting metal roofs or traditional gray shingles, and are usually set back from the road to accommodate agricultural activities.

The town center, marked by a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, houses all of Johnston's businesses. Dining options are limited to three establishments: a family-run Chinese restaurant called Hong Kong, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's burger chain. The town's commercial district includes Maxwell and Halford Drug, a family pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola, and the IGA grocery store, though many residents prefer traveling to Batesburg-Leesville's Walmart for major shopping. Dollar General serves as the town's most popular retailer, while Possibilities Furniture & More and Clark's Cuts and Kennels provide furniture and pet care services respectively.

Healthcare needs are met by small but capable medical and veterinary practices located outside the town center. Education is provided through Johnston Elementary School, with students attending middle and high school in a neighboring town. While the town currently lacks recreational facilities, there are plans to develop a 2.5-acre recreational area to enhance community life and attract visitors. Despite its limited entertainment options and amenities, Johnston maintains its charm as a small, close-knit community that might be easily missed by passing travelers.

I reside in a suburban neighborhood in a small Tennessee town, situated between two state highways. While the through traffic can be a bit heavy, the area is generally peaceful. The community is stable, with minimal resident turnover, allowing me to become familiar with my neighbors. Daily life here revolves around routine activities like yard maintenance and household tasks. During winter, children enjoy sledding on our side street's hill.

Our house occupies a corner lot at the street's entrance, giving us a clear view of all neighborhood activity and passing vehicles. We're quick to notice unfamiliar cars. The community is active, with residents regularly walking for exercise or dog-walking, and children riding their bikes. As a family of four - my wife, our two daughters (11 and 14), and myself - we work from home and are well-integrated into the neighborhood's daily rhythm. We enjoy outdoor activities regardless of weather and occasionally host barbecues on our back deck.

The neighborhood maintains its natural character with numerous trees from its formerly wooded state. This provides ample shade but also means substantial leaf cleanup in autumn. The sound of lawnmowers is constant from spring through fall, and the tradition of burning leaves marks the arrival of autumn. Recent years have brought milder winters, making it feel like extended fall seasons.

Our garage's location at the rear means we primarily use the back entrance. When I'm working in the garage with the doors open, I feel more connected to the community. Holiday periods bring increased activity with visiting relatives and extra parked cars, particularly during Thanksgiving, Christmas, and Mother's Day. Overall, it's a pleasant place to live, though the through-street status is its only notable drawback.

I live in a high desert region characterized by an abundance of dirt and brown landscapes. Those unfamiliar with the area might not grasp how ubiquitous the brown scenery is, and maintaining a green lawn here comes at a considerable expense. The area has evolved since I arrived in the 1990s - while properties remain relatively spread out, new developments have emerged. The region is gradually becoming more urbanized, following a common pattern of development seen elsewhere.

The community is generally welcoming, with both desirable and less desirable areas, typical of any city. My particular section is populated by friendly elderly residents, suggesting a more upscale neighborhood. The retail landscape consists mainly of chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final, with premium retailers requiring some travel to reach. Construction appears to be the dominant industry, likely due to the abundance of undeveloped land - though this ongoing development somewhat concerns me, as I deliberately chose to leave big-city life behind.

My work in construction involves drywall and T-bar installation. One of the area's highlights is its wildlife diversity. The high desert attracts people for various reasons, particularly its distinctive beauty. The unique climate and terrain have created special ecosystems that require protection and host diverse wildlife. Residents should educate themselves about local fauna to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family, especially my three children, has embraced desert living. They're particularly fascinated by local lizards and insects, often spending time observing and catching these creatures. The area offers several attractions, including the San Bernardino County Fair in Victorville, which provides an authentic desert experience. Nearby Wrightwood offers snow activities and winter sports. The Victor Valley Museum showcases the region's natural history, featuring geological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that document the area's social and industrial development.

My description of my neighborhood might be considered unconventional, as I live on a college campus rather than in a traditional residential area. My community consists primarily of my dormitory residents, and to some extent, the broader campus environment. Despite these unique circumstances, my campus neighborhood shares many characteristics with conventional neighborhoods, including various types of housing, residents, commercial establishments, and recreational spaces.

The housing in my area comes in three distinct forms. First, there are apartment buildings, typically two stories high, with each floor containing 4-6 units housing 2-4 people each, accommodating approximately 20 residents per building. Second, there are traditional houses available for rent to those affiliated with the institution, usually occupied by alumni in 2-4 bedroom arrangements, though these are less common. The third and most prevalent type is dormitory housing, where hundreds of students reside, typically with two people sharing a room.

The demographic makeup of our campus neighborhood reflects the institution's commitment to diversity, with residents of various cultural backgrounds and age groups. Professional staff members typically occupy the houses, while students are distributed between dormitories (newer students) and apartments (upperclassmen).

Our self-contained campus neighborhood features numerous amenities, including various dining options, campus-specific clothing stores, and grocery outlets, ensuring residents can access all necessary services within the community. The neighborhood also includes a well-maintained park that serves as a safe, communal recreational space for all community members.

I live in a hilly coastal area where my house is situated at the peak of what locals call the "work out hill," popular among joggers. The neighborhood lacks sidewalks, forcing pedestrians to share the damaged road surface. The infrastructure shows wear, with weather-beaten utility lines frequently requiring repairs due to storm damage.

The area is densely populated with evergreen trees, though residents often remove them to enhance their ocean views. Houses are strategically built on the hillside, featuring large glass windows that capitalize on the bay vista. The sunsets are spectacular when visible, though usually filtered through clouds and haze. The climate is predominantly overcast and humid, leading to moss growth on virtually every surface – I learned this the hard way when my parked car developed a mossy coating after just a month of disuse.

The demographic skews older, with few children despite a nearby school. Dogs are abundant, often roaming freely and occasionally entering homes uninvited. Wildlife is prevalent, including large rabbits (much to gardeners' dismay), various birds from hummingbirds to eagles (though crows keep the larger predators at bay), and my cats have become effective rabbit controllers.

While the neighborhood is residential without nearby shops, the waterfront area below offers seafood restaurants. Though the beach is rocky rather than sandy, it's enjoyable for stone-throwing. The bay itself is relatively narrow, with the opposite shore visible even through typical misty conditions.

Bensonhurst, Brooklyn is easily accessible via NYC's extensive public transit system. This urban neighborhood maintains the quintessential New York City atmosphere while featuring a distinct Asian influence that has developed over the last twenty years. The area is characterized by numerous Asian-owned businesses, particularly supermarkets and laundromats, which are highly regarded by locals for their quality, affordability, and convenience. For instance, within a two-minute walking radius, you can find four Asian supermarkets.

While the Asian presence is significant, Bensonhurst boasts a diverse population comprising immigrants and their first and second-generation American offspring. The neighborhood features a recently upgraded park offering extensive recreational facilities, including basketball and handball courts, soccer/baseball fields, playground equipment, and a summer splash pad, all enjoyed by the area's multicultural community.

The architectural landscape consists mainly of two-family houses, with some co-op and condominium buildings, rather than corporate structures. While the community is generally friendly, noise can be an issue, with loud music from passing cars and revving engines being common disturbances.

Visitors should exercise caution, especially at night. Though relatively safe, the neighborhood has its share of challenges, including occasional harassment, bullying, and theft – particularly package stealing. Additionally, despite city regulations requiring pet owners to clean up after their dogs, compliance is poor, making it necessary to watch your step when walking around the neighborhood.

To grasp Portland, Oregon's essence, one must first understand what "weird" truly means there. The city's unofficial motto, "Keep Portland Weird," adorns a multi-purpose establishment that somehow manages to be a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club all at once, operating in a legally ambiguous space. This slogan represents both nostalgia for a less commercialized Portland of the past and an invitation to those seeking acceptance for their eccentricities.

Despite gentrification and an influx of wealthy newcomers from California, Portland maintains its distinctive character. The city's "weird" identity doesn't imply universal acceptance, but rather an openness to unconventional lifestyles. While Portland has its share of modern amenities and contemporary issues, its uniqueness lies in how it approaches them with a lighter touch.

The city's charm is evident in its neighborhoods, where colorful houses sport urban gardens and residents maintain "free boxes" - informal community exchange points where people leave items for others to discover. These boxes, often containing clothes and books, exemplify Portland's community spirit and serendipitous nature.

Portland encompasses numerous subcultures, from those who practice goat yoga to devoted soccer fans. It's a city where dreams are either pursued passionately or contemplated over craft beers. However, Portland also faces serious challenges, including substance abuse issues (partly attributed to the persistent gloomy weather) and a significant homeless population. The city's response to homelessness, while more progressive than many other places, remains inadequate, and public opinion is divided - a reminder that in some ways, Portland faces the same struggles as any other American city.

The mountains stand as eternal sentinels in the northern horizon, marking each sunrise and sunset with their steadfast presence. Even when daily life distracts me from noticing them, they remain constant and unmoved by temporal concerns. During my most challenging moments, they command my attention, offering solace and renewed strength to persevere.

I discovered these mountains when beginning my university studies, and they immediately captured my imagination. While the campus itself boasts stunning architecture, serene ponds, and magnificent trees that I deeply appreciate, the mountains reign supreme in my heart. The town itself is a delightful mixture of charm and vitality. Students frequent numerous coffee shops for their study sessions, while the downtown area, with its weathered brick buildings housing restaurants and offices, pulses with urban energy. This bustling atmosphere quickly transitions into tranquil residential areas past the library, creating an intriguing blend of environments that invites exploration.

This diverse landscape has become the backdrop for countless memories, both joyful and melancholic. From late-night walks with friends past aging playground equipment to rushed downtown excursions for university-sponsored movie screenings, each corner holds its own story. The campus ponds, particularly, have witnessed both quiet contemplation and emotional breakdowns during early morning hours amid personal crises. While observing the pond's wildlife going about their purposeful lives, I often questioned my own path and place in the world.

During one such moment of reflection, I found myself walking northward along a main street, where palm trees caught the morning light. As I looked up at the sunrise-painted sky, there they were – the mountains, as always, their magnificent peaks touching the dawn's golden-blue canvas. Their silent presence spoke volumes, rekindling my determination to persist despite life's challenges.

At first sight, you might overlook this hidden gem - tucked away behind a shopping center in what appears to be an unlikely residential zone. Beyond the defunct Whole Foods and past the seasonally occupied hotels that mainly come alive for summer family gatherings, you'll discover a thriving neighborhood. The street features several apartment complexes arranged methodically, reminiscent of carefully aligned Russian nesting dolls. While the first complex has a somewhat controversial reputation in local news, the neighboring buildings tell a different story, hosting a vibrant community unknown to most locals.

The area is anchored by a satellite campus of a community college, where drowsy students clutching coffee cups navigate through creaking iron gates each morning, occasionally frustrating rush-hour drivers. The street intersects with another residential road, flanked by a public park and a rehabilitation facility. The treatment center's atmosphere is welcoming, with inviting porch furniture and a gentle ceiling fan stirring the humid summer air.

The park buzzes with activity - children playing freely, bees drifting between flowerbeds, retirees walking their dogs while casting disapproving looks at skateboarding teens, and young girls gathered near the playground discussing pop culture and boys. Adjacent to the park, a modest strip mall houses an affordable sushi restaurant, a pool supply store, and a nail salon, offering convenient one-stop shopping. A self-serve frozen yogurt shop attracts local teenagers, who can often be spotted performing skateboard tricks while enjoying their topped treats and experimenting with vaping, thinking it makes them look cool.

This neighborhood embodies classic Americana - a snapshot of the unhurried South where time seems to stand still, preserving its character through the years.

I live in a distinctive neighborhood characterized by predominantly single-family homes, with a few unique duplex-style properties. Each house, including mine with its modest front yard and side driveway, represents the classic suburban lifestyle that once epitomized the American dream. Though this ideal seems to be fading nationally, our community still embodies its essence, albeit with some visible changes.

The neighborhood retains its character despite showing signs of wear. Children still play in the streets, and driveways remain occupied, though residents' optimism has diminished somewhat. Our 90-year-old public school continues to serve as both an educational institution and a symbol of community heritage. While churches have seen declining attendance, local basketball courts remain active. The homes, though architecturally diverse, share a common spirit.

A notable landmark is the Super "A" supermarket, operated by a Yemeni family who stand out as the area's only Arab residents in a predominantly African American community. The wide streets often serve as impromptu football fields, with games pausing only for passing vehicles. Many residents have deep roots here, sharing stories of a more closely-knit past.

The neighborhood has evolved with time - a former karate school has transformed into a pharmacy, and a charming movie theater showing classic films caters primarily to older residents, while younger ones prefer newer entertainment venues. Our town deliberately remains somewhat isolated, with the nearby expressway having no direct access - a result of older residents successfully opposing such development to preserve the community's character.

As we look to the future with the construction of a new high school and the selection of a town mascot, the suggestion of a cyborg with a country accent and log cabin background perfectly captures our community's blend of traditional values and modern evolution.

I reside in a metropolitan area characterized by its remarkable diversity. The urban landscape features a mix of residential and commercial zones interwoven throughout, with no clear separation between them. The business district encompasses everything from corporate offices to retail shops, dining establishments, and entertainment venues. The commercial scene is vibrant, offering countless dining and shopping options, ranging from major chain stores to trendy independent boutiques. These establishments are found both in shopping centers and along streets that border otherwise peaceful residential areas.

The neighborhood features several parks that are popular among families with children. The demographic makeup is notably diverse, with distinct communities coexisting in close proximity. Within my immediate area, there's a thriving LGBTQ+ population, Orthodox Jewish residents, and a significant community of immigrants from former Soviet states. The broader city features various ethnic enclaves, such as Korea town, China town, and Little Armenia, though they're separated by considerable driving distances due to notorious traffic congestion. Despite some locations being technically close, the city's massive size and traffic issues make walking an impractical option for most residents. This reliance on vehicles contributes to severe parking shortages and some of the world's worst traffic conditions.

Recent years have seen extensive development, particularly in high-rise apartment construction, which has sparked concern among current residents about increasing population density and worsening traffic. Housing options vary considerably, from single-family homes to duplexes, small apartment complexes, and condominiums, all coexisting within the same neighborhood. The area's residents span different age groups, though community bonds aren't as strong as they once were. While I fondly remember playing with neighborhood children during my youth, I now find myself unfamiliar with most of my neighbors, reflecting a shift in community dynamics.

"What's out here?" she inquired as we passed endless cornfields stretching to the horizon. I explained this was all there was, anticipating her amazement at the vast emptiness. Coming from an urban setting where conveniences were just minutes away, she'd never experienced such expansiveness. As I described my upbringing in rural Ohio while surrounded by endless cornfields, she gained a deeper understanding of my background.

The journey to my home takes you down a country road past a water-filled quarry to a small subdivision. The neighborhood features brick and stucco homes, each situated on generous half-acre lots that residents meticulously maintain. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside seasonal Midwestern trees, while luxury Mercedes vehicles sparkle in driveways after weekend washes.

En route to my grey stucco house, you'll spot my elderly Korean neighbor, a former physician who spends his days contentedly mowing and singing, bringing smiles to everyone's faces despite his diminishing mental acuity. My home's side yard hosts geese that our Terrier loves to chase, while the backyard features a stream flowing to the quarry, accompanied by the sounds of bullfrogs and distant farm animals. A handcrafted wooden bridge leads to an untamed sanctuary of indigenous trees, herbs, and wildflowers – my childhood playground where I built forts, chased wildlife, and formed friendships with neighborhood kids.

The harsh winters transform our yard from lush green to stark wilderness, with formerly colorful trees becoming bare silhouettes. Snowfall creates magical scenes, with my sister's snow angels decorating the yard. Our childhood winters were marked by playful snowball fights from our carefully constructed snow forts, complete with stick arsenals. In this personal wonderland, we lived out our carefree childhood fantasies, completely immersed in imaginative play.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the biggest field behind where I live and mosey down to the pond that is not made for swimming. I have seen deer and in the morning you can hear the giant bullfrog singing his song. It is a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by the sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms. It is rather like living in a small community village of it’s own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he is there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle.
